title: It’s Time to Finally Learn Your Gemstone Cuts
text:
An almost-octagonal cut whose flat top and concentric facets draw your eye down into the stone like a deep window

As seen in: Elizabeth Taylor’s Krupp ring

Plays well with: diamonds—the clearer the better

Known for: exclusivity. The sparklier Royal Asscher variation of the cut is patented by one company

Shown above: Ring, $128,000, Bulgari, 212-315-9000

Photo: F. Martin Ramin/The Wall Street Journal; Illustrations by Arthur Mount

Round Brilliant

By far the most popular diamond cut, the round brilliant is also usually the most expensive, sparkliest cut.

As seen in: engagement rings from Oklahoma to Osaka

Plays well with: almost any setting, from pavé to prong solitaire

Known for: its range—you can find a round brilliant in almost any size, at any price point

Shown above: Necklace, $260,000, Graff, 212-421-3605

Photo: F. Martin Ramin/The Wall Street Journal; Illustrations by Arthur Mount

Cabochon

A dome-topped, smooth cut.

As seen in: antique pieces—it dates to the era before precise gem cutting was developed

Plays well with: opaque stones like turquoise. But Los Angeles-based designer Irene Neuwirth also likes it with clear tourmalines

Known for: evoking “earthiness,” according to Ms. Neuwirth

Shown above: Bracelet, $21,500, Verdura, 212-758-3388

Photo: F. Martin Ramin/The Wall Street Journal; Illustrations by Arthur Mount

Pear

Attention-getting teardrop-shaped rocks look larger than other stones of the same weight.

As seen in: Mia Farrow’s engagement ring from Frank Sinatra

Plays well with: solitaire settings, which can show off pears to stunning effect

Known for: being exceptionally high-maintenance: The pointed tip is prone to chipping

Shown above: Sarah Hendler Earrings, $4,100, Metalmark, 720-441-4635

Photo: F. Martin Ramin/The Wall Street Journal; Illustrations by Arthur Mount

Oval

A sophisticated and practical shape that was popular in the late 1950s.

As seen in: the Koh-i-Noor

Plays well with: colored gems (whose flaws can be concealed easily by this cut)

Known for: the illusion of grandeur. Because it has a larger surface area than a comparable round brilliant it creates the appearance of a larger stone

Shown above: Retrouvaí Necklace, $15,330, ylang23.com

Photo: F. Martin Ramin/The Wall Street Journal; Illustrations by Arthur Mount

Emerald

A square or rectangular cut with clipped corners.

As seen in: Grace Kelly’s second engagement ring, which Prince Rainier bought after seeing how Hollywood bling outshone the subtle eternity band he’d first offered

Plays well with: short fingers (it’s elongating when set perpendicularly to the ring)

Known for: flash. The wide facets reflect light well

Shown above: Brent Neale Ring, $14,000, Hirshlefiers, 516-627-3566

Photo: F. Martin Ramin/The Wall Street Journal; Illustrations by Arthur Mount

Cushion

The squoval of gemstone cuts, with elegant rounded corners that give it an old-money look.

As seen in: the Hope Diamond

Plays well with: high-quality colored diamonds and other gemstones, because the cut’s large facets show off color

Known for: versatility. “Chunky” cushions are more mirror-like, “crushed-ice” versions more glittery

Shown above: Schlumberger Earrings, $75,000, Tiffany & Co., 212-755-8000

Photo: F. Martin Ramin/The Wall Street Journal; Illustrations by Arthur Mount

Marquise

Long and pointed, this was reportedly created in the 18th century for King Louis XV, who wanted a diamond that resembled his mistress’s lips.

As seen in: the center of Posh Spice’s first engagement ring

Plays well with: simple diamonds, so the style doesn’t appear overly fussy

Known for: their other, decidedly unappealing moniker of “football cut”

Shown above: Ring, $80,000, Taffin, 212-421-6222
description: Fine jewelry incorporates far more than just the ho-hum round brilliant engagement ring. Here are eight classic cuts to know—whether it’s for shopping inspiration or just pure fantasy.
